insight.title: Why certain apps become impossible to replace once everyone starts using them
insight.subtitle: Exploring the hidden power of the network effect in our daily lives

sections.text: Imagine you are the only person in the world with a telephone. It would be completely useless because you have no one to call. But the moment a second person gets one, the phone suddenly has value. As more people join the network, the value of having a phone doesn’t just grow a little bit; it explodes. This is because every new person who joins creates a new connection for everyone who was already there. In the world of business and technology, we call this the "network effect," and it is the secret engine behind almost every giant company you use today.

This effect creates a powerful cycle that is very hard to stop. Think about why you use a specific social media app or a messaging tool. It usually isn’t because that app has the best buttons or the prettiest colors. You use it because that is where all your friends, family, and coworkers are. If you switched to a brand-new app that was technically better, you would be back to being the person with the only telephone in the world. The true value of the service isn’t in the software itself, but in the massive web of people already connected to it.

Because of this rule, winning in business is often more about being first or growing the fastest rather than having the most expensive features. Once a company reaches a certain size, it becomes a "natural winner" where it is much easier for a new person to join the crowd than to try something new. This explains why it is so difficult for small startups to challenge the giants of the internet. It isn’t just about money or fancy technology; it’s about the fact that a product becomes more useful simply because everyone else is already there.

news.title: Women’s Cancer Risk: Obesity, Hormones & Inactivity
news.description: Obesity, hormonal imbalance, and physical inactivity significantly increase women’s cancer risk, particularly for breast, endometrial, and colorectal cancers. Excess fat raises estrogen and inflammation levels, promoting tumour growth. Experts say even a 10 per cent weight loss, regular exercise, and healthy diet changes can substantially reduce cancer incidence and improve long-term survival. , Health, Times Now

news.title: From roti to OTT: New inflation math tells story of new India
news.description: India's inflation measurement has been updated. The new Consumer Price Index basket shows households now spend less on food and more on services and modern items. This shift reflects a growing economy and changing lifestyles. The Reserve Bank of India's inflation target band has been met. This revision captures how Indians are spending differently today compared to a decade ago.
